pull_request.title: DTLS fixes
pull_request.body:
* Change the size of the `record` buffer in `DtlsRecordLayer.Receive` to be able to hold the actual record. Before, it was sized to fit the decrypted plaintext plus the header, whereas the ciphertext is what's actually sent over the underlying transport.
* `Reset` the `GCMBlockCipher` even when the MAC is invalid, because DTLS needs to be able to decrypt each record independently. Without the reset, corrupt packets can cause the `GCMBlockCipher` object to enter a state in which it will fail to decrypt all subsequent records.
* Ignore `bad_record_mac` "fatal" errors in `DtlsTransport.Receive`, because DTLS is meant to be able to ignore corrupt records.

issue.title: DTLS fixes
issue.body:
* Change the size of the `record` buffer in `DtlsRecordLayer.Receive` to be able to hold the actual record. Before, it was sized to fit the decrypted plaintext plus the header, whereas the ciphertext is what's actually sent over the underlying transport.
* `Reset` the `GCMBlockCipher` even when the MAC is invalid, because DTLS needs to be able to decrypt each record independently. Without the reset, corrupt packets can cause the `GCMBlockCipher` object to enter a state in which it will fail to decrypt all subsequent records.
* Ignore `bad_record_mac` "fatal" errors in `DtlsTransport.Receive`, because DTLS is meant to be able to ignore corrupt records.

comment.body:
I've implemented the ignoring of corrupt records a little bit differently, and there is now a property `TlsPeer.IgnoreCorruptDtlsRecords` to control whether it is enabled (default false to preserve existing behaviour).

I don't really understand the part about the buffer size, so I didn't make that change. It may just be that the code has evolved since you first proposed it, but feel free to open a new issue if you still see a problem in the latest code.

issue.title: Probably a bug in the API in BasicOcspRespGenerator
issue.body:
In method `AddResponse` in [BasicOcspRespGenerator](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/blob/93b32a75656955faf7996d0f3e0ed391968d2ac6/crypto/src/ocsp/BasicOCSPRespGenerator.cs#L148) is optional `thisUpdate` time. But in _RFC 6960_ in ASN1 structure <https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6960#page-15> is optional `nextUpdate` time and `thisUpdate` is required.


Using the current API, it is not possible to create an OCSP response without `nextUpdate`.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate of the Public Key.

I have found that the Y coordinate of the Public Key can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

Hello,

issue.title: configure Signer initialization for Gost2012 algorithms
issue.body:
Hi, faced some issue with Gost-2012 signature verification.
For example for such signature: [signature_with_file.zip](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/files/3845325/signature_with_file.zip)

If I call `SignerInformation.Verify(signerCert)` it throws [SecurityUtilityException ](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/blob/f18a2dbbc2c1b4277e24a2e51f09cac02eedf1f5/crypto/src/security/SignerUtilities.cs#L563)
"1.2.643.7.1.1.2.2WITH1.2.643.7.1.1.1.1 not recognised"

Bouncy castle doesn't know anything about Gost2012 signature algorithm widespread oids (1.2.643.7.1.1.1.1, 1.2.643.7.1.1.1.2), so it can't create DigestSigner object with correct signer and digest at `SignerUtilities.GetSigner(...)`

In PR I add this correct mappings.

By the way, if such configuration can be done by library user, It would be perfect:)

comment.body: These entries have finally been added (with improvements to the SignerUtilities changes).

issue.title: Ant test output can now show incremental progress
issue.body:
This is a simple pull request intended to make it a little easier to run the unit tests from the build scripts.

# Problem
No incremental progress is visible at the command-line when running the unit tests via the build scripts. Without monitoring the contents of the test reports directory, it's impossible to tell if the unit tests are hung or just taking a long time.

# Proposed Solution
This pull request provides the ability for a user to enable test summaries from junit; for each test suite executed, ant will print a two-line summary to the console.

# Details
Added ability to override properties in bc-build.properties with a bc-build.user.properties file, which is ignored by git. The intent is for bc-build.user.properties to hold user-specific settings that are *not* committed to the repository.

Test summaries at the console can be enabled by adding this property to bc-build.user.properties:
```
junit.printsummary: on
```

The default behavior remains unchanged, as the default value for junit.printsummary is false.

comment.body: Just a minor change for the sake of discoverability: could you please add a brief comment at the top of build.properties pointing to the possibility of build.user.properties overrides.

issue.title: BC echoes sensitive information at INFO level
issue.body:
A spring boot app running in container, we are getting the following output logged at INFO level


2021-06-14 21:29:43.552  INFO 405 --- [           main] o.b.jsse.provider.PropertyUtils          : Found string system property [javax.net.ssl.trustStore]: /tmp/myapp/truststore.bcfks
2021-06-14 21:29:43.553  INFO 405 --- [           main] o.b.jsse.provider.PropertyUtils          : Found string system property [javax.net.ssl.trustStoreType]: BCFKS
2021-06-14 21:29:43.568  INFO 405 --- [           main] o.b.jsse.provider.PropertyUtils          : Found string system property [javax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword]: password123
2021-06-14 21:29:43.569  INFO 405 --- [           main] o.b.j.p.ProvTrustManagerFactorySpi       : Initializing with trust store at path: /tmp/myapp/truststore.bcfks
2021-06-14 21:29:44.119  INFO 405 --- [           main] o.b.jsse.provider.PropertyUtils          : Found string system property [javax.net.ssl.keyStore]: /tmp/myapp/keystore.bcfks
2021-06-14 21:29:44.119  INFO 405 --- [           main] o.b.jsse.provider.PropertyUtils          : Found string system property [javax.net.ssl.keyStoreType]: BCFKS
2021-06-14 21:29:44.120  INFO 405 --- [           main] o.b.jsse.provider.PropertyUtils          : Found string system property [javax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword]: password123

Perhaps PropertyUtils should echo the system properties at DEBUG/TRACE levels or scrub out properties that are known to carry sensitive information ("javax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword" and "javax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword")

comment.body: @dhruv459 This was fixed for FIPS in bctls-fips-1.0.12.2.jar (current version 1.0.13). It is only relevant to you if you are using the BCJSSE provider from that jar.

issue.title: Failed to parse the private key file of Ed25519!

comment.body: @dghgit It's not an ENCRYPTED PRIVATE KEY, it's a PRIVATE KEY using PEM encryption. While KeyPairParser supports the PEM encryption (returning a PEMEncryptedKeyPair), PrivateKeyParser doesn't have a pathway to e.g. a "PEMEncryptedPrivateKey".

issue.title: IOException: Unexpected protocol during https TLS1.2 two-way authentication tls handshake on Android Q or above

comment.body:
See javadoc, e.g. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/net/ssl/SSLEngine.html#getApplicationProtocol--:

> null if it has not yet been determined if application protocols might be used for this connection, an empty String if application protocols values will not be used, or a non-empty application protocol String if a value was successfully negotiated.

In any case the empty string is not a valid ProtocolName, (which has length from 1 to 255 (RFC 7301):

`opaque ProtocolName<1..2^8-1>;`

I suggest opening an issue with okhttp.

issue.title: bad_record_mac error as a cause of service rollout restart
issue.body:
Hi,
One of our services implementing Bouncy Castle dependency constantly falls into rollout restart (this service with no Bouncy Castle works normally). What can be seen is in logs is:

redis.clients.jedis.exceptions.JedisConnectionException: org.bouncycastle.tls.TlsFatalAlert: **bad_record_mac(20)**
    at redis.clients.jedis.util.RedisInputStream.ensureFill(RedisInputStream.java:208)
    at redis.clients.jedis.util.RedisInputStream.readByte(RedisInputStream.java:46)
    at redis.clients.jedis.Protocol.process(Protocol.java:126)
   
    (...)
   
Caused by: javax.crypto.AEADBadTagException: Error finalising cipher data: mac check in GCM failed
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:77)
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstanceWithCaller(Constructor.java:499)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:480)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.ClassUtil.throwBadTagException(Unknown Source)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.BaseCipher.engineDoFinal(Unknown Source)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.BaseCipher.engineDoFinal(Unknown Source)
    at java.base/javax.crypto.Cipher.doFinal(Cipher.java:2417)
    at org.bouncycastle.tls.crypto.impl.jcajce.JceAEADCipherImpl.doFinal(JceAEADCipherImpl.java:135)

Current Bouncy Castle version is: 1.0.12.3
The issue can be seen only on one of our evironments. On the other service operates normally. I noticed that on the issued environment the traffic is much bigger than on the others. I've read somewhere, that:
"bad_record_mac could mean some sort of packet corruption on-the-wire, but it's not common in practice (...) it happens with a probability of one in tens of millions"
Taking this into consideration, is it possible that huge traffic is the cause of those **bad_record_mac(20)** errors which cause service rollout restart? If so, what could be possible solution for this situation? Is there a safe 'treshold' for the throughput to avoid these problems?
Thanks in advance for your help

comment.body: @oridool Yes, I intend to write the low-level/direct reproducer myself.

comment.body:
@oridool
- A JVM (or JIT) error with 17 is still in the cards. Still, it seems a little weird to see such an error take an hour of heavy load to trigger. Probably it will be more like a "difference that makes a difference" and not a bug, but we'll see.
- The error is very suggestive of a race condition, but you are reporting that it still occurs single-threaded, so it would have to be something more exotic like a race b/w the user thread and the finalizer thread.
- Other users have previously reported memory usage problems that ultimately stem from high memory usage by AES/GCM (and sometimes resulting finalizer queue issues), and the 1-2 hour trigger aligns with that, although there's nothing obvious in the exception related to that.

Practically speaking, the next step should be to simplify the reproducer to something that just hammers AES/GCM decryption (maybe encryption also needs to be included), basically by lifting the code out of TLS.

pull_request.title: Implement support for raw public keys (RFC 7250)
pull_request.body: Implement support for raw public keys, as described in RFC 7250 and RFC 8446 (section 4.4.2 especially). Also added tests to validate the implementation. Note that only TLS 1.2 is tested since BC's support for 1.3 isn't finished yet, but these changes should not create any additional work for 1.3.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate of the Public Key.

I have found that the Y coordinate of the Public Key can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
Well the X coordinate alone is ambiguous, since there are two possible public keys with any given X coordinate. Either there is some unstated assumption about which key is meant, or something else is missing in your description.

`ECCurve.DecodePoint` is the way to do what you are trying to do, but to do that you need to either be given the 33-byte compressed key, or I guess there could be a rule that says you always prepend 0x02 (or 0x03) to the X coordinate to create the compressed key.

Note that calculating the square root yourself doesn't escape the issue since there are two roots to choose from.

issue.title: Expose PGPObjectFactory.nextObject(BCPGInputStream, KeyFingerprintCal…
issue.body:
…culator)

By exposing the nextObject() method as a static method, it can be used more flexibly.

The reason for this PR is, that `PGPObjectFactory` wraps any stream it gets as constructor argument into a `BCPGInputStream`, regardless of whether that stream might already be a `BCPGInputStream`.
That has the effect, that the stream that got passed into the factory is forwarded too far when parsing objects.

By exposing the `nextObject()` method statically, we have the option to avoid the wrapping, so that the stream is only read so far as needed.

comment.body:
> An alternative solution would be to check if the InputStream argument in the PGPObjectFactory constructor is already a BCPGInputStream. If it is, we can set the inputstream field in the PGPObjectFactory to the constructor argument directly instead of wrapping it.

This would be a better choice, as there is already a method `PGPKeyRing.wrap` used for the same purpose by `PGPPublicKeyRing` and `PGPSecretKeyRing` for the same purpose. Also, the bc-csharp code already uses `Wrap` in `PgpObjectFactory` as described (although the method has been moved to `BcpgInputStream`, which might be a good idea here too).

comment.body:
@oridool It's not clear to me that your tests with the non-FIPS BC providers would actually be using GCM cipher suites, since in that case our client offers CHACHA20_POLY1305 suites at higher priority. Could you please try the non-FIPS version with an explicit cipher suite configured e.g. TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256.

We'd also like to rule out any issues stemming from the java version (17 IIUC), so if it's possible, please test the FIPS version with Java 11. While VM bugs aren't all that common, we do occasionally hit them, so this check would be helpful.

Hi,
One of our services implementing Bouncy Castle dependency constantly falls into rollout restart (this service with no Bouncy Castle works normally). What can be seen is in logs is:

redis.clients.jedis.exceptions.JedisConnectionException: org.bouncycastle.tls.TlsFatalAlert: **bad_record_mac(20)**
    at redis.clients.jedis.util.RedisInputStream.ensureFill(RedisInputStream.java:208)

    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:77)
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstanceWithCaller(Constructor.java:499)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:480)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.ClassUtil.throwBadTagException(Unknown Source)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.BaseCipher.engineDoFinal(Unknown Source)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.BaseCipher.engineDoFinal(Unknown Source)
    at java.base/javax.crypto.Cipher.doFinal(Cipher.java:2417)
    at org.bouncycastle.tls.crypto.impl.jcajce.JceAEADCipherImpl.doFinal(JceAEADCipherImpl.java:135)

Current Bouncy Castle version is: 1.0.12.3
The issue can be seen only on one of our evironments. On the other service operates normally. I noticed that on the issued environment the traffic is much bigger than on the others. I've read somewhere, that:
"bad_record_mac could mean some sort of packet corruption on-the-wire, but it's not common in practice (...) it happens with a probability of one in tens of millions"
Taking this into consideration, is it possible that huge traffic is the cause of those **bad_record_mac(20)** errors which cause service rollout restart? If so, what could be possible solution for this situation? Is there a safe 'treshold' for the throughput to avoid these problems?
Thanks in advance for your help

comment.body:
> How can we proceed from here ?

Can you disable GCM cipher suites in TLS 1.2 and try that please (e.g. configure your client so that only TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256 is supported, or some other non-GCM suite).

> Do you want to provide a potential fix by a new build/jar and try it ?

I'm just hoping to isolate the issue to GCM, then we can investigate and, yes, provide you a new jar once we've a potential fix.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate of the Public Key.

I have found that the Y coordinate of the Public Key can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
Are you sure you have "the X coordinate" and not a compressed public key? The X coordinate by itself would be a 32 byte value (and by itself it would not tell you which of two possible public keys it corresponds to - i.e. which square root), while a compressed public key would be 33 bytes beginning with a 0x02 or 0x03 byte.

If it's the 33 byte compressed key, then you just use `curve.DecodePoint` and it will handle the details.

issue.title: ChaCha20Poly1305 AAD_LIMIT overflows
issue.body: In bac5367 `AAD_LIMIT` limit was from `Long.MAX_VALUE` to `Long.MAX_VALUE - Long.MIN_VALUE`, which overflows resulting in a practical value of -1. It doesn't appear possible to have a `AAD_LIMIT` value of 2^64 - 1 without using `BigInteger` instead of `long`.

comment.body: It's being used as an unsigned 64 bit value in calculations. So -1 actually means 2^64 - 1; see the `incrementCount` method. Let us know if you think there is a problem with it in operation.
This is a false positive. Better remove this change and let us review the file separately.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate.

I have found that the Y coordinate can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
An EC private key doesn't have an X coordinate, rather it is just a single scalar (it's the public key that is a point with X,Y coordinates). You could construct a private key object as follows:

```
Org.BouncyCastle.Math.BigInteger d = ...; // this would be the value you've been given
Org.BouncyCastle.Crypto.Parameters.ECDomainParameters dp = Org.BouncyCastle.Asn1.X9.ECNamedCurveTable.GetByName("P-256");
var privateKey = new Org.BouncyCastle.Crypto.Parameters.ECPrivateKeyParameters(d, dp);

```
and that could then be e.g. used with an ISigner of some kind to verify a signature. You'd need to provide more details about the signature to know exactly how.

comment.body:
> I was trying to reproduce the issue with bcprov+bctls 1.71 and even 1.69 but with no success.
> It doesn't occur when using these jars.

@oridool That's interesting information. Could you please also test bcprov+bctls 1.72b15 from [here](https://downloads.bouncycastle.org/betas/), so we can be sure the SSLEngine changes won't regress this.

bc-fips+bctls-fips is not _exactly_ the same JSSE code; there are some relatively small changes to adapt to using the FIPS crypto. Taken together with this:

> When it happens, it happens together for almost all threads at the same time.

...it suggests some kind of issue with either the FIPS AES/GCM implementation itself or perhaps in the thin layer of bctls-fips that uses it. A race condition of some kind still seems likely. We will review the codepath into the FIPS jar and look for what could be a possible cause.

Could you clarify which TLS version your reproducer is using? I am interested specifically in whether there is a difference b/w TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3, as there is a special nonce mechanism for TLS GCM only used by the FIPS version in TLS 1.2.

issue.title: Bouncy Castle is throwing "mac check in OCB failed" when trying to decrypt an AES message

comment.body: The specification BC follows is [RFC 7253](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7253), which AFAICT pycryptodome also claims to follow. Our test suite includes the test vectors from Appendix A. It would be worth establishing first that pycryptodome also passes those test vectors.

issue.title: Implement support for raw public keys (RFC 7250)
issue.body: Implement support for raw public keys, as described in RFC 7250 and RFC 8446 (section 4.4.2 especially). Also added tests to validate the implementation. Note that only TLS 1.2 is tested since BC's support for 1.3 isn't finished yet, but these changes should not create any additional work for 1.3.

issue.body:

        }

}  `

org.bouncycastle.tls.TlsFatalAlert: certificate_unknown(46)

comment.body:
From v1.70, use -Dorg.bouncycastle.jsse.client.assumeOriginalHostName=true instead of -Djdk.tls.trustNameService=true. The new property additionally sets the SNI hostname, and is specific to BCJSSE, which is probably desirable. If stuck on an earlier version you would probably have to use e.g. Apache HttpClient instead, which doesn't suffer from the HttpsURLConnection bug relating to hostname setting on third-party JSSE providers (https://github.com/bcgit/bc-java/issues/660).

The SNI hostname makes the difference in this case because https://login.microsoftonline.us is apparently a virtual server that relies on the SNI information to choose its certificate. There follow some redirects ending up on an azure portal, which complicates things a bit, but with the new property it all works smoothly.

pull_request.title: DTLS fixes
pull_request.body:
* Change the size of the `record` buffer in `DtlsRecordLayer.Receive` to be able to hold the actual record. Before, it was sized to fit the decrypted plaintext plus the header, whereas the ciphertext is what's actually sent over the underlying transport.
* `Reset` the `GCMBlockCipher` even when the MAC is invalid, because DTLS needs to be able to decrypt each record independently. Without the reset, corrupt packets can cause the `GCMBlockCipher` object to enter a state in which it will fail to decrypt all subsequent records.
* Ignore `bad_record_mac` "fatal" errors in `DtlsTransport.Receive`, because DTLS is meant to be able to ignore corrupt records.

issue.title: DTLS fixes
issue.body:
* Change the size of the `record` buffer in `DtlsRecordLayer.Receive` to be able to hold the actual record. Before, it was sized to fit the decrypted plaintext plus the header, whereas the ciphertext is what's actually sent over the underlying transport.

issue.title: Probably a bug in the API in BasicOcspRespGenerator
issue.body:
In method `AddResponse` in [BasicOcspRespGenerator](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/blob/93b32a75656955faf7996d0f3e0ed391968d2ac6/crypto/src/ocsp/BasicOCSPRespGenerator.cs#L148) is optional `thisUpdate` time. But in _RFC 6960_ in ASN1 structure <https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6960#page-15> is optional `nextUpdate` time and `thisUpdate` is required.


Using the current API, it is not possible to create an OCSP response without `nextUpdate`.

For example for such signature: [signature_with_file.zip](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/files/3845325/signature_with_file.zip)

issue.title: Ant test output can now show incremental progress
issue.body:
This is a simple pull request intended to make it a little easier to run the unit tests from the build scripts.

# Problem
No incremental progress is visible at the command-line when running the unit tests via the build scripts. Without monitoring the contents of the test reports directory, it's impossible to tell if the unit tests are hung or just taking a long time.

# Proposed Solution
This pull request provides the ability for a user to enable test summaries from junit; for each test suite executed, ant will print a two-line summary to the console.

# Details
Added ability to override properties in bc-build.properties with a bc-build.user.properties file, which is ignored by git. The intent is for bc-build.user.properties to hold user-specific settings that are *not* committed to the repository.

Test summaries at the console can be enabled by adding this property to bc-build.user.properties:
```
junit.printsummary: on
```

The default behavior remains unchanged, as the default value for junit.printsummary is false.

comment.body: Just a minor change for the sake of discoverability: could you please add a brief comment at the top of build.properties pointing to the possibility of build.user.properties overrides.

issue.title: Failed to parse the private key file of Ed25519!

comment.body: @dghgit It's not an ENCRYPTED PRIVATE KEY, it's a PRIVATE KEY using PEM encryption. While KeyPairParser supports the PEM encryption (returning a PEMEncryptedKeyPair), PrivateKeyParser doesn't have a pathway to e.g. a "PEMEncryptedPrivateKey".

issue.title: IOException: Unexpected protocol during https TLS1.2 two-way authentication tls handshake on Android Q or above

comment.body:
See javadoc, e.g. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/net/ssl/SSLEngine.html#getApplicationProtocol--:

> null if it has not yet been determined if application protocols might be used for this connection, an empty String if application protocols values will not be used, or a non-empty application protocol String if a value was successfully negotiated.

In any case the empty string is not a valid ProtocolName, (which has length from 1 to 255 (RFC 7301):

`opaque ProtocolName<1..2^8-1>;`

I suggest opening an issue with okhttp.

redis.clients.jedis.exceptions.JedisConnectionException: org.bouncycastle.tls.TlsFatalAlert: **bad_record_mac(20)**

    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:77)

    at org.bouncycastle.tls.crypto.impl.jcajce.JceAEADCipherImpl.doFinal(JceAEADCipherImpl.java:135)

comment.body:
@oridool
- A JVM (or JIT) error with 17 is still in the cards. Still, it seems a little weird to see such an error take an hour of heavy load to trigger. Probably it will be more like a "difference that makes a difference" and not a bug, but we'll see.
- The error is very suggestive of a race condition, but you are reporting that it still occurs single-threaded, so it would have to be something more exotic like a race b/w the user thread and the finalizer thread.
- Other users have previously reported memory usage problems that ultimately stem from high memory usage by AES/GCM (and sometimes resulting finalizer queue issues), and the 1-2 hour trigger aligns with that, although there's nothing obvious in the exception related to that.

Practically speaking, the next step should be to simplify the reproducer to something that just hammers AES/GCM decryption (maybe encryption also needs to be included), basically by lifting the code out of TLS.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate of the Public Key.

I have found that the Y coordinate of the Public Key can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
Well the X coordinate alone is ambiguous, since there are two possible public keys with any given X coordinate. Either there is some unstated assumption about which key is meant, or something else is missing in your description.

`ECCurve.DecodePoint` is the way to do what you are trying to do, but to do that you need to either be given the 33-byte compressed key, or I guess there could be a rule that says you always prepend 0x02 (or 0x03) to the X coordinate to create the compressed key.

Note that calculating the square root yourself doesn't escape the issue since there are two roots to choose from.

issue.title: Expose PGPObjectFactory.nextObject(BCPGInputStream, KeyFingerprintCal…
issue.body:
…culator)

By exposing the nextObject() method as a static method, it can be used more flexibly.

The reason for this PR is, that `PGPObjectFactory` wraps any stream it gets as constructor argument into a `BCPGInputStream`, regardless of whether that stream might already be a `BCPGInputStream`.
That has the effect, that the stream that got passed into the factory is forwarded too far when parsing objects.

By exposing the `nextObject()` method statically, we have the option to avoid the wrapping, so that the stream is only read so far as needed.

comment.body:
> An alternative solution would be to check if the InputStream argument in the PGPObjectFactory constructor is already a BCPGInputStream. If it is, we can set the inputstream field in the PGPObjectFactory to the constructor argument directly instead of wrapping it.

This would be a better choice, as there is already a method `PGPKeyRing.wrap` used for the same purpose by `PGPPublicKeyRing` and `PGPSecretKeyRing` for the same purpose. Also, the bc-csharp code already uses `Wrap` in `PgpObjectFactory` as described (although the method has been moved to `BcpgInputStream`, which might be a good idea here too).

@oridool It's not clear to me that your tests with the non-FIPS BC providers would actually be using GCM cipher suites, since in that case our client offers CHACHA20_POLY1305 suites at higher priority. Could you please try the non-FIPS version with an explicit cipher suite configured e.g. TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256.

We'd also like to rule out any issues stemming from the java version (17 IIUC), so if it's possible, please test the FIPS version with Java 11. While VM bugs aren't all that common, we do occasionally hit them, so this check would be helpful.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate of the Public Key.

I have found that the Y coordinate of the Public Key can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
Are you sure you have "the X coordinate" and not a compressed public key? The X coordinate by itself would be a 32 byte value (and by itself it would not tell you which of two possible public keys it corresponds to - i.e. which square root), while a compressed public key would be 33 bytes beginning with a 0x02 or 0x03 byte.

If it's the 33 byte compressed key, then you just use `curve.DecodePoint` and it will handle the details.

issue.title: ChaCha20Poly1305 AAD_LIMIT overflows
issue.body: In bac5367 `AAD_LIMIT` limit was from `Long.MAX_VALUE` to `Long.MAX_VALUE - Long.MIN_VALUE`, which overflows resulting in a practical value of -1. It doesn't appear possible to have a `AAD_LIMIT` value of 2^64 - 1 without using `BigInteger` instead of `long`.

comment.body: It's being used as an unsigned 64 bit value in calculations. So -1 actually means 2^64 - 1; see the `incrementCount` method. Let us know if you think there is a problem with it in operation.
This is a false positive. Better remove this change and let us review the file separately.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate.

I have found that the Y coordinate can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
An EC private key doesn't have an X coordinate, rather it is just a single scalar (it's the public key that is a point with X,Y coordinates). You could construct a private key object as follows:

```
Org.BouncyCastle.Math.BigInteger d = ...; // this would be the value you've been given
Org.BouncyCastle.Crypto.Parameters.ECDomainParameters dp = Org.BouncyCastle.Asn1.X9.ECNamedCurveTable.GetByName("P-256");
var privateKey = new Org.BouncyCastle.Crypto.Parameters.ECPrivateKeyParameters(d, dp);

```
and that could then be e.g. used with an ISigner of some kind to verify a signature. You'd need to provide more details about the signature to know exactly how.

comment.body:
> I was trying to reproduce the issue with bcprov+bctls 1.71 and even 1.69 but with no success.
> It doesn't occur when using these jars.

@oridool That's interesting information. Could you please also test bcprov+bctls 1.72b15 from [here](https://downloads.bouncycastle.org/betas/), so we can be sure the SSLEngine changes won't regress this.

bc-fips+bctls-fips is not _exactly_ the same JSSE code; there are some relatively small changes to adapt to using the FIPS crypto. Taken together with this:

> When it happens, it happens together for almost all threads at the same time.

...it suggests some kind of issue with either the FIPS AES/GCM implementation itself or perhaps in the thin layer of bctls-fips that uses it. A race condition of some kind still seems likely. We will review the codepath into the FIPS jar and look for what could be a possible cause.

Could you clarify which TLS version your reproducer is using? I am interested specifically in whether there is a difference b/w TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3, as there is a special nonce mechanism for TLS GCM only used by the FIPS version in TLS 1.2.

issue.title: Bouncy Castle is throwing "mac check in OCB failed" when trying to decrypt an AES message

comment.body: The specification BC follows is [RFC 7253](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7253), which AFAICT pycryptodome also claims to follow. Our test suite includes the test vectors from Appendix A. It would be worth establishing first that pycryptodome also passes those test vectors.

issue.title: Implement support for raw public keys (RFC 7250)
issue.body: Implement support for raw public keys, as described in RFC 7250 and RFC 8446 (section 4.4.2 especially). Also added tests to validate the implementation. Note that only TLS 1.2 is tested since BC's support for 1.3 isn't finished yet, but these changes should not create any additional work for 1.3.

comment.body:
From v1.70, use -Dorg.bouncycastle.jsse.client.assumeOriginalHostName=true instead of -Djdk.tls.trustNameService=true. The new property additionally sets the SNI hostname, and is specific to BCJSSE, which is probably desirable. If stuck on an earlier version you would probably have to use e.g. Apache HttpClient instead, which doesn't suffer from the HttpsURLConnection bug relating to hostname setting on third-party JSSE providers (https://github.com/bcgit/bc-java/issues/660).

The SNI hostname makes the difference in this case because https://login.microsoftonline.us is apparently a virtual server that relies on the SNI information to choose its certificate. There follow some redirects ending up on an azure portal, which complicates things a bit, but with the new property it all works smoothly.

pull_request.title: DTLS fixes
pull_request.body:
* Change the size of the `record` buffer in `DtlsRecordLayer.Receive` to be able to hold the actual record. Before, it was sized to fit the decrypted plaintext plus the header, whereas the ciphertext is what's actually sent over the underlying transport.
* `Reset` the `GCMBlockCipher` even when the MAC is invalid, because DTLS needs to be able to decrypt each record independently. Without the reset, corrupt packets can cause the `GCMBlockCipher` object to enter a state in which it will fail to decrypt all subsequent records.
* Ignore `bad_record_mac` "fatal" errors in `DtlsTransport.Receive`, because DTLS is meant to be able to ignore corrupt records.

issue.title: DTLS fixes
issue.body:
* Change the size of the `record` buffer in `DtlsRecordLayer.Receive` to be able to hold the actual record. Before, it was sized to fit the decrypted plaintext plus the header, whereas the ciphertext is what's actually sent over the underlying transport.
* `Reset` the `GCMBlockCipher` even when the MAC is invalid, because DTLS needs to be able to decrypt each record independently. Without the reset, corrupt packets can cause the `GCMBlockCipher` object to enter a state in which it will fail to decrypt all subsequent records.
* Ignore `bad_record_mac` "fatal" errors in `DtlsTransport.Receive`, because DTLS is meant to be able to ignore corrupt records.

I've implemented the ignoring of corrupt records a little bit differently, and there is now a property `TlsPeer.IgnoreCorruptDtlsRecords` to control whether it is enabled (default false to preserve existing behaviour).

I don't really understand the part about the buffer size, so I didn't make that change. It may just be that the code has evolved since you first proposed it, but feel free to open a new issue if you still see a problem in the latest code.

issue.title: Probably a bug in the API in BasicOcspRespGenerator
issue.body:
In method `AddResponse` in [BasicOcspRespGenerator](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/blob/93b32a75656955faf7996d0f3e0ed391968d2ac6/crypto/src/ocsp/BasicOCSPRespGenerator.cs#L148) is optional `thisUpdate` time. But in _RFC 6960_ in ASN1 structure <https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6960#page-15> is optional `nextUpdate` time and `thisUpdate` is required.


Using the current API, it is not possible to create an OCSP response without `nextUpdate`.

For example for such signature: [signature_with_file.zip](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/files/3845325/signature_with_file.zip)

If I call `SignerInformation.Verify(signerCert)` it throws [SecurityUtilityException ](https://github.com/bcgit/bc-csharp/blob/f18a2dbbc2c1b4277e24a2e51f09cac02eedf1f5/crypto/src/security/SignerUtilities.cs#L563)

issue.title: Ant test output can now show incremental progress
issue.body:
This is a simple pull request intended to make it a little easier to run the unit tests from the build scripts.

# Problem
No incremental progress is visible at the command-line when running the unit tests via the build scripts. Without monitoring the contents of the test reports directory, it's impossible to tell if the unit tests are hung or just taking a long time.

# Proposed Solution
This pull request provides the ability for a user to enable test summaries from junit; for each test suite executed, ant will print a two-line summary to the console.

# Details
Added ability to override properties in bc-build.properties with a bc-build.user.properties file, which is ignored by git. The intent is for bc-build.user.properties to hold user-specific settings that are *not* committed to the repository.

Test summaries at the console can be enabled by adding this property to bc-build.user.properties:
```
junit.printsummary: on
```

The default behavior remains unchanged, as the default value for junit.printsummary is false.

comment.body: Just a minor change for the sake of discoverability: could you please add a brief comment at the top of build.properties pointing to the possibility of build.user.properties overrides.

comment.body: @dghgit It's not an ENCRYPTED PRIVATE KEY, it's a PRIVATE KEY using PEM encryption. While KeyPairParser supports the PEM encryption (returning a PEMEncryptedKeyPair), PrivateKeyParser doesn't have a pathway to e.g. a "PEMEncryptedPrivateKey".

issue.title: IOException: Unexpected protocol during https TLS1.2 two-way authentication tls handshake on Android Q or above

comment.body:
See javadoc, e.g. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/javax/net/ssl/SSLEngine.html#getApplicationProtocol--:

> null if it has not yet been determined if application protocols might be used for this connection, an empty String if application protocols values will not be used, or a non-empty application protocol String if a value was successfully negotiated.

In any case the empty string is not a valid ProtocolName, (which has length from 1 to 255 (RFC 7301):

`opaque ProtocolName<1..2^8-1>;`

I suggest opening an issue with okhttp.

comment.body:
@oridool
- A JVM (or JIT) error with 17 is still in the cards. Still, it seems a little weird to see such an error take an hour of heavy load to trigger. Probably it will be more like a "difference that makes a difference" and not a bug, but we'll see.
- The error is very suggestive of a race condition, but you are reporting that it still occurs single-threaded, so it would have to be something more exotic like a race b/w the user thread and the finalizer thread.
- Other users have previously reported memory usage problems that ultimately stem from high memory usage by AES/GCM (and sometimes resulting finalizer queue issues), and the 1-2 hour trigger aligns with that, although there's nothing obvious in the exception related to that.

Practically speaking, the next step should be to simplify the reproducer to something that just hammers AES/GCM decryption (maybe encryption also needs to be included), basically by lifting the code out of TLS.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate of the Public Key.

I have found that the Y coordinate of the Public Key can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
Well the X coordinate alone is ambiguous, since there are two possible public keys with any given X coordinate. Either there is some unstated assumption about which key is meant, or something else is missing in your description.

`ECCurve.DecodePoint` is the way to do what you are trying to do, but to do that you need to either be given the 33-byte compressed key, or I guess there could be a rule that says you always prepend 0x02 (or 0x03) to the X coordinate to create the compressed key.

Note that calculating the square root yourself doesn't escape the issue since there are two roots to choose from.

issue.title: Expose PGPObjectFactory.nextObject(BCPGInputStream, KeyFingerprintCal…
issue.body:
…culator)

By exposing the nextObject() method as a static method, it can be used more flexibly.

The reason for this PR is, that `PGPObjectFactory` wraps any stream it gets as constructor argument into a `BCPGInputStream`, regardless of whether that stream might already be a `BCPGInputStream`.
That has the effect, that the stream that got passed into the factory is forwarded too far when parsing objects.

By exposing the `nextObject()` method statically, we have the option to avoid the wrapping, so that the stream is only read so far as needed.

comment.body:
> An alternative solution would be to check if the InputStream argument in the PGPObjectFactory constructor is already a BCPGInputStream. If it is, we can set the inputstream field in the PGPObjectFactory to the constructor argument directly instead of wrapping it.

This would be a better choice, as there is already a method `PGPKeyRing.wrap` used for the same purpose by `PGPPublicKeyRing` and `PGPSecretKeyRing` for the same purpose. Also, the bc-csharp code already uses `Wrap` in `PgpObjectFactory` as described (although the method has been moved to `BcpgInputStream`, which might be a good idea here too).

issue.title: bad_record_mac error as a cause of service rollout restart
issue.body:
Hi,
One of our services implementing Bouncy Castle dependency constantly falls into rollout restart (this service with no Bouncy Castle works normally). What can be seen is in logs is:

redis.clients.jedis.exceptions.JedisConnectionException: org.bouncycastle.tls.TlsFatalAlert: **bad_record_mac(20)**
    at redis.clients.jedis.util.RedisInputStream.ensureFill(RedisInputStream.java:208)
    at redis.clients.jedis.util.RedisInputStream.readByte(RedisInputStream.java:46)
    at redis.clients.jedis.Protocol.process(Protocol.java:126)
   
    (...)
   
Caused by: javax.crypto.AEADBadTagException: Error finalising cipher data: mac check in GCM failed
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:77)
    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstanceWithCaller(Constructor.java:499)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:480)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.ClassUtil.throwBadTagException(Unknown Source)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.BaseCipher.engineDoFinal(Unknown Source)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.BaseCipher.engineDoFinal(Unknown Source)
    at java.base/javax.crypto.Cipher.doFinal(Cipher.java:2417)
    at org.bouncycastle.tls.crypto.impl.jcajce.JceAEADCipherImpl.doFinal(JceAEADCipherImpl.java:135)

Current Bouncy Castle version is: 1.0.12.3
The issue can be seen only on one of our evironments. On the other service operates normally. I noticed that on the issued environment the traffic is much bigger than on the others. I've read somewhere, that:
"bad_record_mac could mean some sort of packet corruption on-the-wire, but it's not common in practice (...) it happens with a probability of one in tens of millions"
Taking this into consideration, is it possible that huge traffic is the cause of those **bad_record_mac(20)** errors which cause service rollout restart? If so, what could be possible solution for this situation? Is there a safe 'treshold' for the throughput to avoid these problems?
Thanks in advance for your help

comment.body:
@oridool It's not clear to me that your tests with the non-FIPS BC providers would actually be using GCM cipher suites, since in that case our client offers CHACHA20_POLY1305 suites at higher priority. Could you please try the non-FIPS version with an explicit cipher suite configured e.g. TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256.

We'd also like to rule out any issues stemming from the java version (17 IIUC), so if it's possible, please test the FIPS version with Java 11. While VM bugs aren't all that common, we do occasionally hit them, so this check would be helpful.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate of the Public Key.

I have found that the Y coordinate of the Public Key can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
Are you sure you have "the X coordinate" and not a compressed public key? The X coordinate by itself would be a 32 byte value (and by itself it would not tell you which of two possible public keys it corresponds to - i.e. which square root), while a compressed public key would be 33 bytes beginning with a 0x02 or 0x03 byte.

If it's the 33 byte compressed key, then you just use `curve.DecodePoint` and it will handle the details.

issue.title: ChaCha20Poly1305 AAD_LIMIT overflows
issue.body: In bac5367 `AAD_LIMIT` limit was from `Long.MAX_VALUE` to `Long.MAX_VALUE - Long.MIN_VALUE`, which overflows resulting in a practical value of -1. It doesn't appear possible to have a `AAD_LIMIT` value of 2^64 - 1 without using `BigInteger` instead of `long`.

comment.body: It's being used as an unsigned 64 bit value in calculations. So -1 actually means 2^64 - 1; see the `incrementCount` method. Let us know if you think there is a problem with it in operation.
This is a false positive. Better remove this change and let us review the file separately.

issue.title: EC Public Key Calculate Y Coordinate from X
issue.body:
I am currently in need of verifying a block of data signed with a private EC key (P-256) and only have access to the X coordinate.

I have found that the Y coordinate can be calculated by using the following formula:

y^2 = b + x ( a + x^2) 

Which is mostly achievable, however there is no BigInteger Square Root function that I can find. 

Could you please point me towards a Square Root function or possibly where I may be going wrong / something I have missed?

comment.body:
An EC private key doesn't have an X coordinate, rather it is just a single scalar (it's the public key that is a point with X,Y coordinates). You could construct a private key object as follows:

```
Org.BouncyCastle.Math.BigInteger d = ...; // this would be the value you've been given
Org.BouncyCastle.Crypto.Parameters.ECDomainParameters dp = Org.BouncyCastle.Asn1.X9.ECNamedCurveTable.GetByName("P-256");
var privateKey = new Org.BouncyCastle.Crypto.Parameters.ECPrivateKeyParameters(d, dp);

```
and that could then be e.g. used with an ISigner of some kind to verify a signature. You'd need to provide more details about the signature to know exactly how.

comment.body:
> I was trying to reproduce the issue with bcprov+bctls 1.71 and even 1.69 but with no success.
> It doesn't occur when using these jars.

@oridool That's interesting information. Could you please also test bcprov+bctls 1.72b15 from [here](https://downloads.bouncycastle.org/betas/), so we can be sure the SSLEngine changes won't regress this.

bc-fips+bctls-fips is not _exactly_ the same JSSE code; there are some relatively small changes to adapt to using the FIPS crypto. Taken together with this:

> When it happens, it happens together for almost all threads at the same time.

...it suggests some kind of issue with either the FIPS AES/GCM implementation itself or perhaps in the thin layer of bctls-fips that uses it. A race condition of some kind still seems likely. We will review the codepath into the FIPS jar and look for what could be a possible cause.

Could you clarify which TLS version your reproducer is using? I am interested specifically in whether there is a difference b/w TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3, as there is a special nonce mechanism for TLS GCM only used by the FIPS version in TLS 1.2.

    at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
    at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstanceWithCaller(Constructor.java:499)

    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.ClassUtil.throwBadTagException(Unknown Source)
    at org.bouncycastle.jcajce.provider.BaseCipher.engineDoFinal(Unknown Source)

Current Bouncy Castle version is: 1.0.12.3
The issue can be seen only on one of our evironments. On the other service operates normally. I noticed that on the issued environment the traffic is much bigger than on the others. I've read somewhere, that:
"bad_record_mac could mean some sort of packet corruption on-the-wire, but it's not common in practice (...) it happens with a probability of one in tens of millions"
Taking this into consideration, is it possible that huge traffic is the cause of those **bad_record_mac(20)** errors which cause service rollout restart? If so, what could be possible solution for this situation? Is there a safe 'treshold' for the throughput to avoid these problems?
Thanks in advance for your help

comment.body: @oridool It might provide useful information to try the reproducer with the regular BC library (bcprov + bctls jars). I would be interested in results from both the latest release (1.71) as well as the latest beta (1.72b15 - available from https://downloads.bouncycastle.org/betas/). In particular the beta version features a rewritten SSLEngine implementation (which will eventually find its way into the FIPS version), so if the issue is with our SSLEngine there's some chance that it resolves the issue.

issue.title: Bouncy Castle is throwing "mac check in OCB failed" when trying to decrypt an AES message

comment.body: The specification BC follows is [RFC 7253](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7253), which AFAICT pycryptodome also claims to follow. Our test suite includes the test vectors from Appendix A. It would be worth establishing first that pycryptodome also passes those test vectors.

issue.title: Implement support for raw public keys (RFC 7250)
issue.body: Implement support for raw public keys, as described in RFC 7250 and RFC 8446 (section 4.4.2 especially). Also added tests to validate the implementation. Note that only TLS 1.2 is tested since BC's support for 1.3 isn't finished yet, but these changes should not create any additional work for 1.3.

}  `

**Problem**
Using BC we found the following situation when we try to go against https://login.microsoftonline.us

org.bouncycastle.tls.TlsFatalAlert: certificate_unknown(46)

Caused by: java.security.cert.CertificateException: No subject alternative name found matching domain name login.microsoftonline.us
	at org.bouncycastle.jsse.provider.HostnameUtil.checkHostname(HostnameUtil.java:97)

This works if we try it with https://login.microsoftonline.com and we found that BC always try to match hostname in the URL with 2nd entry in "SubjectAlternativeName/DNSName" in the certificate.

1. [login.microsoftonline.us](https://login.microsoftonline.us/)

    SubjectAlternativeName [
     DNSName: [login.microsoftonline.us](https://login.microsoftonline.us/)
     DNSName: [certauth.login.microsoftonline.us](https://certauth.login.microsoftonline.us/)
     DNSName: [device.login.microsoftonline.us](https://device.login.microsoftonline.us/)
     DNSName: [logincert.microsoftonline.us](https://logincert.microsoftonline.us/)
    ]

 2. [login.microsoftonline.com](https://login.microsoftonline.com/)
     SubjectAlternativeName [
     DNSName: [stamp2.login.microsoftonline.com](https://stamp2.login.microsoftonline.com/)
     DNSName: [login.microsoftonline-int.com](https://login.microsoftonline-int.com/)
     DNSName: [login.microsoftonline-p.com](https://login.microsoftonline-p.com/)
     DNSName: [login.microsoftonline.com](https://login.microsoftonline.com/)
     DNSName: [login2.microsoftonline-int.com](https://login2.microsoftonline-int.com/)
     DNSName: [login2.microsoftonline.com](https://login2.microsoftonline.com/)
     DNSName: [loginex.microsoftonline-int.com](https://loginex.microsoftonline-int.com/)
     DNSName: [loginex.microsoftonline.com](https://loginex.microsoftonline.com/)
     DNSName: [stamp2.login.microsoftonline-int.com](https://stamp2.login.microsoftonline-int.com/)
    ]

How we can see the 2nd entry in https://login.microsoftonline.us/ has certauth and it doesn’t match, but in https://login.microsoftonline.com/ the 2nd entry has login and in this case works.

**Step to reproduce**
1. Generate the app with the code shared
2. Configure BC in your environment 
3. Run the following command /DIRECTORY-OF-YOUR-APP/java -Djdk.tls.trustNameService=true BCExample https://login.microsoftonline.us

comment.body:
From v1.70, use -Dorg.bouncycastle.jsse.client.assumeOriginalHostName=true instead of -Djdk.tls.trustNameService=true. The new property additionally sets the SNI hostname, and is specific to BCJSSE, which is probably desirable. If stuck on an earlier version you would probably have to use e.g. Apache HttpClient instead, which doesn't suffer from the HttpsURLConnection bug relating to hostname setting on third-party JSSE providers (https://github.com/bcgit/bc-java/issues/660).

The SNI hostname makes the difference in this case because https://login.microsoftonline.us is apparently a virtual server that relies on the SNI information to choose its certificate. There follow some redirects ending up on an azure portal, which complicates things a bit, but with the new property it all works smoothly.
